Summary: The proposal aims to enhance the interpretability of deep neural networks by integrating sparse autoencoders for feature disentanglement and graph-based visualization for interactive exploration. It targets both vision and language models, with a focus on quantitative interpretability metrics and human-in-the-loop evaluation.
Strengths: Addresses a critical and timely problem in deep learning interpretability.
Innovative hybrid approach combining disentanglement and visualization.
Detailed experimental plan with clear milestones.
Includes quantitative metrics for evaluating interpretability.
Weaknesses: Novelty of the proposed method is limited, building heavily on existing techniques.
Lacks detailed technical solutions for key challenges like scalability and feature purity.
Execution plan is not sufficiently detailed to assess feasibility.
Human-in-the-loop evaluation may introduce subjectivity and scalability issues.
Questions: How will the proposed method scale to very large models like GPT-3 or ViT-Large?
What are the specific technical challenges in training sparse autoencoders on high-dimensional activations?
How will the subjectivity of human-aligned concepts be addressed in the evaluation?
What are the computational costs of the proposed method, especially for large models?
Limitations: Scalability of the method to very large models is uncertain.
Feature purity may degrade with increasing model complexity.
Human-in-the-loop evaluation may introduce subjectivity and scalability issues.
The method may not generalize well across diverse architectures and tasks.
